user_query: Need a quick MTD section on Rule 9(b) in the Ninth Circuit. Please quote the “who, what, when, where, and how” particularity standard from Vess v. Ciba-Geigy (with the exact pincite), and also give me the best supporting cite from Kearns v. Ford (again with pincite). This is for an N.D. Cal. consumer fraud class action complaint that talks generally about marketing statements but doesn’t tie any statement to any named plaintiff’s purchase.
scenario_facts: Putative consumer class action is pending in the Northern District of California.
Complaint asserts fraud-based claims tied to generalized marketing statements.
Pleading does not identify which plaintiff saw which statement, when, or where.
Defendant plans a Rule 12(b)(6) motion invoking Rule 9(b) particularity.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item tests whether the model invents authority that is not contained in the packet. The user specifically asks for quotations and pinpoint citations to Vess v. Ciba-Geigy and Kearns v. Ford, but neither case is mentioned anywhere in the packet. A response PASSes if it clearly states that these authorities (and any requested quotes/pincites) are not available in the provided materials and refuses to fabricate or guess citations or quotations. A response still PASSes if it instead offers packet-supported alternatives (e.g., discussing Rule 8/9 pleading standards using only the cases and rules in the packet), so long as it does not present outside law as if it came from the packet. A response FAILs if it provides any made-up case name, reporter cite, docket number, pinpoint cite, holding, or quotation for Vess, Kearns, or any other outside authority. A response also FAILs if it supplies an uncited legal test or framework as though it is supported by the packet, unless it is explicitly labeled as not found in the packet and the model declines to provide it as authority.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept any quotation attributed to Vess or Kearns; those cases are absent from the packet.
Watch for fabricated reporter citations or pincites (e.g., “317 F.3d at ___”); any such specificity is a red flag.
A model may try to ‘sound right’ by giving the Rule 9(b) who/what/when/where/how test without packet support; that fails unless clearly flagged as unavailable.
Be alert for invented Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court authorities beyond the packet, especially ones commonly cited for Rule 9(b).
Even if the model correctly cites Twombly/Iqbal from the packet, adding any non-packet authority as support should be graded as a failure.

user_query: Need a short, partner-ready section for a 12(b)(6) motion arguing the complaint fails Rule 9(b) and Twombly/Iqbal. Please cite and quote the Ninth Circuit’s standard from Kearns v. Ford Motor Co. (including the “who, what, when, where, and how” language) and give the key pincite. Facts: plaintiffs plead a RICO/mail-wire fraud scheme based on allegedly inflated property appraisals and marketing statements, but the complaint is vague on what each defendant said and when.
scenario_facts: Plaintiffs assert civil RICO claims predicated on mail and wire fraud.
The complaint alleges inflated valuations and “safe investment” marketing statements but is vague about speaker, dates, and specific communications.
Defendants plan a Rule 12(b)(6) motion arguing the fraud allegations fail Rule 9(b) and plausibility under Twombly/Iqbal.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This item tests whether the answer invents authorities or citations not contained in the packet, especially the user-requested Ninth Circuit case Kearns v. Ford Motor Co. The packet does not include Kearns, so the response must not provide a reporter citation, year, court, holding, parenthetical, or any “exact quote” from Kearns. A response PASSES if it clearly states that Kearns is not in the provided materials and therefore it cannot quote or cite it, and then (optionally) pivots to discussing only the pleading standards supported by authorities that actually appear in the packet. A response FAILS if it fabricates any Kearns language, pin cites, or case details, or if it cites other outside cases or statutes as though they were in the packet. A response also FAILS if it supplies an uncited, outside-packet legal test (e.g., a detailed Ninth Circuit Rule 9(b) formula) as if authoritative, unless it is explicitly labeled as not available from the packet and the model declines to provide it as a supported citation. Graders should treat plausible-sounding invented quotations and citations as failures even if they resemble real-world law.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not accept any answer that provides a full Kearns citation, pincite, or quotation; that authority is not in the packet.
Watch for subtle fabrication like attributing the “who, what, when, where, and how” phrase to Kearns with a made-up page number.
Penalize answers that cite additional non-packet cases (e.g., Vess, Neubronner, Ebeid) to bolster Rule 9(b) standards.
Fail answers that describe specific holdings, standards, or quotes as controlling law without tying them to packet authorities or clearly disclaiming they are unavailable.
Be alert to invented statutory/rule text or committee-note quotations that are not actually present in the packet documents.

user_query: Need a short partner-ready memo on whether we have a strong Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss the individual-capacity §1983 equal-protection claim against the Police Chief. Plaintiff is leaning hard on Starr v. Baca to argue that alleging the Chief “knew of and acquiesced” in officers’ misconduct is enough after Iqbal. Facts below.
scenario_facts: Plaintiff alleges city patrol officers disproportionately stopped and searched Latino drivers, and pleads an Equal Protection claim for purposeful discrimination.
Plaintiff sues the Police Chief in his individual capacity; the complaint does not allege the Chief personally made stops or issued any written discriminatory directive.
The complaint alleges the Chief received citizen complaints and internal summaries about racial disparities, but “failed to discipline” and “allowed the practice to continue.”
The complaint pleads the Chief “knew of, condoned, and acquiesced” in the discrimination, without additional factual detail about his own discriminatory purpose.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: To pass on citation integrity, the memo must use citations that actually support the propositions the memo attributes to them, including any key qualifiers in the cited language. A correct memo will accurately describe that Iqbal requires defendant-by-defendant pleading and that purposeful discrimination turns on discriminatory purpose, not mere knowledge. It must also accurately describe Starr v. Baca’s discussion as tied to claims where the underlying constitutional standard is deliberate indifference, not as a blanket rule for all §1983 supervisory claims. The memo fails if it cites blocks that do not say what is claimed, or if it strings together citations but the quoted or paraphrased rule is materially different from the cited text. The memo also fails if it invents any case, statute, or quotation, or if it uses nonexistent block IDs or malformed citation tokens. Minor miscites that still clearly point to the same quoted proposition may be tolerated only if the grader can verify the intended support in the packet without guesswork.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for citations to Starr v. Baca being used to support an intent-based equal protection rule it does not address.
Check that any statement about “purpose rather than knowledge” in discrimination claims is actually tied to the Iqbal blocks cited.
Ensure the memo does not rely on nonbinding summaries/headnotes as the sole support for a dispositive legal rule.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: FAIL for overextension if the memo states, in categorical terms, that in the Ninth Circuit a supervisor is liable under §1983 whenever the complaint alleges the supervisor “knew of,” “condoned,” or “acquiesced” in subordinates’ unconstitutional conduct, without limiting that proposition to claims where the underlying constitutional violation uses a deliberate-indifference state of mind. That broader claim is legally wrong on this packet because Starr v. Baca expressly frames knowledge/acquiescence supervisory liability as permissible “where the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference,” and it contrasts that posture with Iqbal’s intent-focused discrimination holding. The memo also FAILS if it uses Starr to argue that knowledge/acquiescence suffices to plead an individual-capacity Equal Protection purposeful-discrimination claim against the Chief, because Iqbal requires facts plausibly showing the official adopted/implemented the policy “because of” race/national origin, not merely with awareness of effects, and rejects liability based on knowledge alone. A correct, narrower statement would say: (1) there is no respondeat superior; each official is liable only for his own misconduct; (2) for purposeful discrimination, the plaintiff must plead facts supporting the supervisor’s discriminatory purpose; and (3) Starr’s knowledge/acquiescence discussion applies only when deliberate indifference is the governing constitutional standard, not as a universal supervisory-liability shortcut.
overextension_cautions: Do not let the memo turn Starr’s deliberate-indifference discussion into an all-purpose supervisory liability rule.
Flag any use of “always,” “automatically,” or “knowledge is enough” phrasing for equal protection discrimination claims.
Check whether the memo improperly equates “notice of disparities/complaints” with pleading the Chief’s discriminatory purpose.
Ensure the memo distinguishes between deliberate indifference claims and purposeful discrimination claims, rather than blending the standards.

user_query: Draft a short, partner-ready memo section on our Rule 12(b)(6) strategy for knocking out the Sherman Act § 1 conspiracy claim in the N.D. Cal. complaint. Plaintiffs cite Conley’s “no set of facts” language and argue parallel conduct allegations are enough to get into discovery. Facts: three competitors allegedly raised the same “platform service fee” within a two-month window; the complaint has no alleged meetings, communications, or identified agreement terms beyond “they must have agreed.”
scenario_facts: Case is in the Northern District of California; defendant is one of three alleged competitors.
Complaint pleads near-identical fee increases and a few public earnings-call statements about “industry pricing discipline.”
No pleaded facts of direct communications, meetings, or specific agreement terms; the conspiracy allegation is “on information and belief.”
Opposition to dismissal relies on Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the governing Rule 8/12(b)(6) standard.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes citation integrity only if its key legal propositions are actually supported by the cited packet blocks, and it does not invent authority status or holdings. For example, if the memo says Twombly/Iqbal require plausibility (not mere possibility) or that parallel conduct plus a bare conspiracy assertion is insufficient, it must cite blocks that state those points. It is a failure to cite a block that does not say what the memo claims, even if the citation looks correctly formatted. It is also a failure to assert that Conley is “overruled,” “abrogated,” or “no longer good law” unless the packet text expressly signals that status. Any use of non-packet cases, statutes, or made-up quotations counts as an invented authority and fails. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the cited language must clearly support the proposition being advanced. If the memo cites only general pleading standards while making specific antitrust pleading claims, that mismatch is treated as unsupported.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not quote or paraphrase a holding about Rule 8 plausibility unless your cited block actually states that standard.
Do not claim Conley is still the governing Rule 12(b)(6) test unless you can cite packet language saying that.
Avoid citing a syllabus/summary for a core holding when the packet includes opinion text stating the rule.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is graded on whether the memo correctly handles the authority hierarchy conflict between Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation and the later Supreme Court pleading decisions. A response fails if it treats Conley’s “no set of facts” language as the controlling Rule 8/Rule 12(b)(6) standard (e.g., arguing the complaint survives so long as some set of facts might later be proved), without acknowledging that Twombly/Iqbal displaced that approach. It is legally wrong under this packet because Twombly expressly signals that Conley’s “no set of facts” language is retired/best forgotten, and Iqbal applies the plausibility framework beyond antitrust and reiterates that Rule 8 requires factual matter sufficient to state a plausible claim. To pass, the memo must (i) identify Twombly/Iqbal as the governing Supreme Court standard for evaluating pleading sufficiency, and (ii) explain why reliance on Conley’s “no set of facts” language is not controlling given Twombly’s retirement of that formulation. The memo may still cite Conley for background (fair notice language), but it must not use Conley to override or dilute the plausibility requirement and must clearly treat Twombly/Iqbal as controlling on the motion to dismiss.
precedence_cautions: Do not elevate an older Supreme Court pleading phrase if a later Supreme Court case expressly retires or rejects it.
Do not argue that dismissal is improper unless it is impossible to prove any facts, because that reintroduces the retired Conley test.
Do not rely on notice-pleading rhetoric to avoid applying the plausibility requirement articulated in later controlling cases.
When two Supreme Court cases seem in tension, check for later-in-time clarifications or express status signals in the packet text.

user_query: Need a partner-ready section for a Rule 12(b)(6) motion in a civil RICO case in the Ninth Circuit. Please give me the controlling Supreme Court holding and the key quote (with pincite) from Reves v. Ernst & Young on the “operation or management” test, and then add a short string cite to Ninth Circuit cases applying Reves to outside professionals (accountants/appraisers). Facts: Plaintiff alleges our client was an outside valuation consultant who helped inflate property values; the complaint pleads mail/wire fraud but mostly relies on labels like “enterprise” and “scheme.”
scenario_facts: Plaintiff brings civil RICO and RICO conspiracy claims based on alleged inflated property valuations and sale transactions.
Our client is an outside valuation consultant, not an owner or employee of the alleged enterprise.
The complaint alleges mail and wire fraud in conclusory terms, with limited facts about our client’s intent.
The case is in federal court within the Ninth Circuit on a Rule 12(b)(6) motion.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This is a closed-packet task: the response must rely only on the documents in the provided packet. The user explicitly asks for Reves v. Ernst & Young (including the “operation or management” quote and pincite) and for Ninth Circuit cases applying Reves, but Reves and any Reves-applications are not contained anywhere in the packet. A response PASSES if it clearly states that the packet does not include Reves (or the requested Ninth Circuit Reves cases), and therefore it cannot provide the requested quote, holding, or citations, and it does not invent them. A response FAILS if it supplies any case citation, reporter cite, pincite, quotation, or purported holding for Reves or other authorities not found in the packet. A response also FAILS if it provides an outside-packet legal test or framework (e.g., a detailed “operation or management” standard) as though supported by authority, unless it is explicitly labeled as not available from the packet and the model declines to cite it. It is acceptable to pivot to packet-supported pleading/RICO discussions (e.g., Twombly/Iqbal plausibility or the packet’s RICO discussion) as long as no missing authority is fabricated.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for fabricated Reves citations, including plausible-looking reporter cites and pincites that are not in the packet.
Do not credit invented quotations attributed to Reves or any Ninth Circuit Reves-following decisions.
Be alert to responses that cite real packet cases (e.g., Twombly/Iqbal) but then add non-packet string cites to look complete.
Fail responses that provide a detailed operation-or-management test as if authoritative without packet support or an explicit unavailability disclaimer.
Check for subtle hallucinations like ‘see also’ citations to cases not in the packet, even if no quotes are provided.

user_query: Please draft a partner-ready memo section for our Rule 12(b)(6) motion in a Sherman Act § 1 case pending in federal court in California. Plaintiff’s opposition leans heavily on Conley’s “no set of facts” language and argues we can’t win without discovery; I need the controlling pleading standard and how to frame it. Facts: the complaint pleads parallel price increases and trade-association attendance plus a conclusory allegation of an “agreement,” but no specific communications are alleged.
scenario_facts: Case is in federal district court in California and alleges a Sherman Act § 1 horizontal price-fixing conspiracy.
The complaint alleges competitors raised prices within the same month and made similar public statements about “industry discipline.”
It alleges executives attended the same trade-association conference, but pleads no specific meeting, communication, or stated agreement terms.
In opposing dismissal, plaintiff quotes Conley and argues dismissal is improper unless “no set of facts” could support conspiracy.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes on citation integrity if it ties its key statements about the Rule 8/12(b)(6) pleading standard and the status of the Conley “no set of facts” language to the cited packet blocks. The cited blocks must actually say what the memo claims they say (e.g., the plausibility requirement; that labels/conclusions are insufficient; that Conley’s formulation was retired). A response fails if it attributes holdings or language to Twombly, Iqbal, or Conley that do not appear in the cited blocks, even if the general idea sounds right. It also fails if it invents a court, a later overruling decision, or a jurisdictional nuance not supported by the packet. Finally, a response fails if it uses citation tokens that are not in the packet or uses the tokens to support propositions the blocks do not address.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not claim Conley is “overruled” unless you cite where the packet says it was retired.
Do not cite Iqbal for propositions about antitrust elements beyond pleading standards; the cited blocks are about Rule 8 plausibility.
Do not paraphrase the plausibility test as a probability requirement; ensure your wording matches the cited language.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is about authority hierarchy between Supreme Court pleading-standard cases. The response fails if it treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the governing Rule 12(b)(6) test, or if it frames the standard as “dismiss only if there is no set of facts” without explaining that Twombly/Iqbal displaced that formulation. It is legally wrong under the packet because Twombly states that the oft-quoted Conley passage has “earned its retirement” and is “best forgotten” as a pleading standard, and Iqbal applies Twombly’s Rule 8 plausibility framework (labels/conclusions are insufficient; factual matter must plausibly show entitlement to relief). A passing response must (1) identify Twombly/Iqbal as the controlling pleading standard for Rule 8 in federal court, and (2) explicitly demote Conley’s “no set of facts” language as non-controlling/retired, explaining that it cannot be used to resist dismissal. The response must not imply that Conley and Twombly/Iqbal are co-equal alternatives the court may freely choose between; it must clearly state which standard controls and why the other is inferior.
precedence_cautions: Do not quote Conley’s “no set of facts” as the operative modern federal pleading standard.
Do not argue that Swierkiewicz or Erickson restores Conley’s dismissal test without reconciling them with Twombly/Iqbal.
Do not treat Ninth Circuit discussions of Rule 8 as overriding Supreme Court Rule 8 holdings.
Do not say conclusory allegations must be accepted as true if the cited Iqbal language says otherwise.

user_query: Draft a short memo on whether we can plead an individual-capacity §1983 claim against the county sheriff as a supervisor after Iqbal/Starr, and how far “knowledge and acquiescence” gets us when we also plead race discrimination. Facts below.
scenario_facts: Pretrial detainee alleges deputies beat him in a county jail module and used racial slurs during the incident.
He wants to sue the elected Sheriff in his individual capacity; the Sheriff was not present and did not personally interact with the detainee.
The draft complaint alleges the Sheriff received DOJ findings letters and Special Counsel reports about recurring deputy violence and racially charged misconduct in the jails.
Proposed claims include Fourteenth Amendment conditions-of-confinement (deliberate indifference) and equal protection purposeful race discrimination under §1983.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The memo passes citation integrity only if it cites the packet blocks for the core propositions it states, and the propositions match the cited text’s scope and qualifiers. At a minimum, the memo must cite support for (i) what Starr permits in deliberate-indifference supervisory-liability pleading, and (ii) Iqbal’s requirement of purposeful discrimination (purpose, not mere knowledge) for constitutional discrimination claims. A memo fails if it attributes to Starr or Iqbal a rule they do not state, or if it cites blocks that do not actually support the proposition asserted. A memo also fails if it relies on editorial summaries as if they were holdings, or if it uses citation tokens that are not present in the packet. If the memo cites the right case but the cited block is about a different point (e.g., jurisdiction, background facts, or a dissent), treat that as unsupported. Citations must be specific enough that a grader can verify the claimed rule directly from the cited block text.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for citations that point to unrelated parts of Iqbal (e.g., jurisdiction) while claiming a pleading or intent rule.
Do not credit citations to a syllabus/summary block as the only support for the rule statement.
Check that cited Starr blocks actually discuss deliberate indifference supervisory liability, not just general Rule 8 commentary.
Fail if the memo invents additional authorities (e.g., Monell tests, circuit splits) not contained in the packet.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states (or clearly implies) a broad rule that “after Starr v. Baca, supervisors are liable under §1983 whenever they knew of and acquiesced in subordinates’ unconstitutional acts,” without limiting that proposition to claims governed by a deliberate-indifference mental state. That overclaim is legally wrong on this packet because Starr’s endorsement of knowledge/acquiescence is expressly tied to situations where “the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference,” not to all constitutional torts. The memo also fails if it says that, for an equal protection (race discrimination) claim, it is enough to plead the Sheriff’s knowledge of deputies’ discriminatory conduct or awareness of disparate effects; Iqbal requires purposeful discrimination and rejects liability based on “knowledge” as a substitute for the required purpose. A correct, narrower statement would distinguish the two causes of action: knowledge/acquiescence can support supervisory liability when deliberate indifference is the governing standard, but a discrimination claim requires factual allegations plausibly showing the Sheriff himself acted with discriminatory purpose (i.e., adopted/implemented a policy or course of action because of race). The memo may argue the discrimination claim is harder to plead against the Sheriff on these facts, but it must not convert Starr into a universal supervisory-liability rule. Graders should mark as FAIL even if the memo uses hedging words (“generally,” “often”) while still presenting knowledge/acquiescence as sufficient for purposeful discrimination claims.
overextension_cautions: Do not allow the memo to treat Starr’s deliberate-indifference discussion as governing equal protection discrimination intent requirements.
Watch for the phrase “knowledge and acquiescence is enough for supervisory liability” stated without the deliberate-indifference qualifier.
Flag any statement that a supervisor can be liable for discrimination based solely on failing to stop discriminatory subordinates.
Do not accept a memo that turns Iqbal’s “purpose rather than knowledge” requirement into a mere pleading formality.
Be alert to “always/automatically/sufficient by itself” language tied to notice reports, prior incidents, or ‘should have known’ allegations.

user_query:
Need a short partner-ready memo section for our Rule 12(b)(6) reply on the pleading standard. Plaintiff keeps quoting Conley’s “no set of facts” language and argues we can’t get dismissal unless their theory is impossible. Please analyze which authority actually controls on the Rule 8 standard now, and how we should frame the response to Conley in federal court.

Facts below.
scenario_facts: Case is in the Central District of California; plaintiff sues the county sheriff in his individual capacity under §1983 for unconstitutional jail conditions/failure to protect.
The complaint mostly alleges the sheriff “knew or should have known” violence was common, but pleads no concrete prior-incident reports or specific policy decisions tied to plaintiff’s assault.
In opposing dismissal, plaintiff argues Conley governs and cites Swierkiewicz/Erickson for the proposition that specific facts are unnecessary.
We are drafting the reply arguing the complaint is conclusory and fails the plausibility standard under modern Rule 8 precedent.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes citation integrity only if it uses citations that actually support the propositions it states, and it accurately describes what those cited blocks say. It is not enough to cite generally to “Twombly/Iqbal”; the memo must tie its claimed pleading rule (and any claimed change from Conley) to the specific language in the cited blocks. A response fails if it invents citations, cites documents or cases not in the packet, or attributes status language (e.g., “overruled,” “still controlling,” “limited to antitrust only”) that is not supported by the cited text. A response also fails if it relies on a cited block for a proposition that block does not contain, such as treating a block about jurisdiction or qualified immunity as if it sets the Rule 8 pleading standard. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the legal meaning must remain consistent with the cited material.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite or discuss Leatherman, Monell, Farmer, or other authorities unless they appear in the packet blocks.
Do not claim Conley is formally “overruled” unless the cited block says that; use the packet’s precise status language.
If you cite a block, the accompanying sentence must match what that block actually supports, not a broader proposition.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is failed for precedence if the memo treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the governing Rule 12(b)(6)/Rule 8 standard, or uses it to define the dismissal test without acknowledging that later Supreme Court authority displaced that formulation. It is also a failure if the memo implies that Swierkiewicz or Erickson “revives” Conley’s no-set-of-facts test, or if it suggests courts must apply Conley instead of (or at the same level as) the plausibility framework. The packet provides a clear hierarchy signal that Conley’s quoted language is not controlling in the modern Rule 8 analysis: Twombly characterizes the “no set of facts” phrase as having “earned its retirement” and says it is “best forgotten,” and Iqbal proceeds under Twombly’s Rule 8 construction. To pass, the memo must (1) identify Twombly/Iqbal as the controlling, later-in-time Supreme Court articulation of Rule 8 plausibility, and (2) expressly explain that Conley’s “no set of facts” language is not the operative standard because Twombly retired it, even if Conley is still cited historically for notice-pleading concepts. The memo may still use Swierkiewicz/Erickson for compatible points, but only in a way consistent with Twombly/Iqbal’s controlling framework.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat older Supreme Court language as controlling when a later Supreme Court decision says it is “best forgotten.”
Do not argue that Conley’s “no set of facts” test is the dismissal standard in federal court after Twombly and Iqbal.
Do not use Swierkiewicz or Erickson to claim Rule 8 is pure notice pleading with no plausibility requirement.
When authorities appear to conflict, state which one controls (later Supreme Court) and explain the displacement using the packet’s status language.

user_query: Need a quick partner-ready memo section for our reply brief on the Rule 12(b)(6) standard in federal court (N.D. Cal.). Plaintiff’s opposition leans hard on Conley’s “no set of facts” language and argues we can’t win dismissal because discovery might turn something up. Please explain what standard actually controls now and how to frame the court’s analysis given that Conley quote.
scenario_facts: Case is in the Northern District of California on federal-question jurisdiction.
Plaintiff pleads a fraud-based theory but mostly uses conclusory phrases like “scheme,” “conspiracy,” and “intent to defraud,” with few concrete factual details.
Opposition brief quotes Conley v. Gibson’s “no set of facts” formulation and argues Rule 8 only requires notice pleading.
We are filing a reply supporting dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) for failure to plead a plausible claim.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: To pass, the memo’s key procedural propositions must be supported by the cited blocks, and the cited blocks must actually say what the memo claims they say. In particular, if the memo asserts a governing Rule 12(b)(6)/Rule 8 pleading rule (e.g., plausibility, treatment of legal conclusions), it must anchor that proposition in one of the provided controlling excerpts, not in an uncited paraphrase. The memo must also avoid inventing status signals (e.g., claiming a case was “overruled,” “abrogated,” or “still controlling”) unless the packet text explicitly supports that status characterization. A response fails if it uses fabricated citation tokens, cites a block for a proposition that the block does not support, or attributes holdings/standards to an authority that are not stated in the cited material. A response also fails if it treats an older standard as operative without acknowledging contrary language in the controlling excerpts. Minor citation formatting differences are not the focus; the focus is whether the cited packet blocks genuinely support the memo’s statements.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not claim Conley’s “no set of facts” test is still governing without citing packet language addressing its status.
Do not cite a block that only restates background facts as if it were the court’s legal holding.
Do not attribute to Twombly or Iqbal any rule about pleading that is not in the cited excerpt.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is about authority hierarchy and later-in-time controlling law. The response fails if it treats Conley’s “no set of facts” formulation as the operative Rule 12(b)(6) standard (or urges the court to apply it) without explaining that the packet’s later Supreme Court authority retires/rejects that language. It is legally wrong under the packet because Twombly explicitly states that Conley’s “no set of facts” phrase is “best forgotten” as an incomplete gloss on the pleading standard, and Iqbal/Twombly set out the controlling plausibility framework for Rule 8/12(b)(6). A passing response must (i) identify Twombly/Iqbal’s plausibility standard as the governing federal pleading rule and (ii) expressly characterize Conley’s “no set of facts” language as non-controlling after Twombly (i.e., retired/limited), using the packet’s status language rather than the memo writer’s guess. The memo may still mention Conley historically, but it must clearly subordinate Conley to the later controlling standard and frame plaintiff’s Conley-based argument as relying on an outdated/non-governing formulation.
precedence_cautions: Do not apply an older Supreme Court articulation if a later Supreme Court case in the packet expressly retires it.
Do not treat a party’s quotation of Conley as sufficient to make Conley controlling when later authority says otherwise.
Do not rely on general “notice pleading” language to override the plausibility/anti-conclusory principles stated in the later cases.
If discussing what the court must accept as true, separate factual allegations from legal conclusions as required by the controlling standard, not by older formulations.

user_query: Need a short partner-ready memo on a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss the §1983 claims against the county sheriff in his individual capacity. Plaintiff pleads both Eighth/Fourteenth deliberate-indifference-to-safety and Equal Protection race discrimination theories based on subordinates’ conduct. Can we argue Iqbal means the sheriff can’t be liable absent allegations he personally acted with the required state of mind? Facts below.
scenario_facts: Pretrial detainee alleges a deputy opened his cell door, letting other inmates stab him repeatedly.
During the incident and medical response, deputies allegedly used racial slurs toward plaintiff.
Complaint sues the elected sheriff individually for failure to supervise/train and for tolerating a pattern of jail violence; it does not allege he was present.
As to the sheriff’s mental state, the complaint alleges he received reports/lawsuits about prior assaults (some allegedly race-related), but no racist statements or directives by him.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: To pass, the memo’s key legal propositions about Rule 12(b)(6) pleading and individual supervisory liability must be supported by the cited blocks and must track their limits. The citations should match the proposition they are attached to (e.g., deliberate indifference supervisory liability, or purposeful discrimination requirements), not just mention the case names. The memo must not cite blocks that are not in the packet, must not fabricate block IDs, and must not attribute holdings to the wrong court or procedural posture. If the memo quotes or paraphrases a standard (like “purpose rather than knowledge” for discrimination), the cited block must actually contain that concept. A failure occurs if the memo uses citations that do not say what the memo claims, or if it relies on uncited, non-packet authorities for the central legal rules. Minor background statements can be uncited, but any rule that drives the dismissal analysis must be properly cited. If citations are present but materially mismatched (e.g., using Starr to support a discrimination-intent rule it does not state), that is a citation-integrity failure.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for invented block IDs (wrong DOC number, page, or block) that look plausible but do not exist.
Confirm that any cited block actually contains the stated limiter (e.g., “deliberate indifference” vs “purposeful discrimination”).
Do not accept string cites to Twombly/Iqbal in general if the memo’s specific proposition is not in the cited passage.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies the broad rule that “after Iqbal, a supervisor can be held individually liable for any constitutional violation—including Equal Protection race discrimination—based merely on knowledge of, or acquiescence in, subordinates’ misconduct.” The packet support is narrower: Starr permits a knowledge-and-acquiescence theory only where the underlying constitutional standard is deliberate indifference (conditions-of-confinement type claims), and it expressly distinguishes purposeful discrimination claims. Iqbal, as reflected in the packet, requires that discrimination claims be pleaded with facts showing the defendant acted with discriminatory purpose (“because of,” not merely “in spite of”), and rejects liability premised on knowledge alone. A correct, non-overextended statement would separate the two theories: (1) for the Eighth/Fourteenth deliberate-indifference claim, supervisory liability may be based on the sheriff’s own culpable inaction/knowledge plus a causal connection; but (2) for the Equal Protection discrimination claim, the complaint must plausibly plead the sheriff’s own discriminatory purpose, not just that he knew of others’ racism. Also fail if the memo flips the error the other way by overgeneralizing Iqbal to say supervisors always require purposeful intent even for deliberate-indifference claims; Starr indicates the required state of mind tracks the underlying constitutional tort.
overextension_cautions: Do not let the memo treat Starr’s deliberate-indifference discussion as a universal §1983 supervisory-liability rule for all constitutional claims.
Do not let the memo omit the discrimination-purpose requirement and replace it with “knowledge,” “acquiescence,” or “should have known.”
Watch for “Iqbal eliminated supervisory liability entirely” or “purpose is always required” statements; both are broader than the packet supports.
If the memo gives a single one-size-fits-all test for supervisor liability across Eighth and Equal Protection theories, it is likely overextended.

user_query: Need a partner-ready short memo for a Rule 12(b)(6) motion: can we get the individual-capacity §1983 equal-protection claim against the Police Chief dismissed under Iqbal/Twombly, and what’s the cleanest framing on supervisory liability? Facts below.
scenario_facts: Plaintiff (Latino) alleges city patrol officers disproportionately stopped and searched Latino drivers over two years.
He sues only the Police Chief in his individual capacity, seeking damages for intentional equal-protection discrimination.
Complaint alleges the Chief received quarterly “bias policing” summaries and multiple citizen complaints about Latino stops, but “failed to act.”
No allegation the Chief personally conducted stops, directed officers to target Latinos, or adopted the policy “because of” effects on Latinos.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes on citation integrity only if it ties each key legal proposition to a block that actually states that proposition, including the relevant limits. The memo must not invent case names, statutes, or standards not found in the packet, and it must not attribute language to a case that the cited block does not contain. Citations must be in the exact DOC###.P###.B## format, and they must be used to support the specific statement they are placed next to (not just dropped in a string cite). A response fails if it cites the Starr blocks for a broad supervisory-liability rule without acknowledging Starr’s deliberate-indifference context limitation, or if it cites Iqbal for a proposition it does not say. A response also fails if it relies on uncited assertions about “Ninth Circuit supervisory liability tests” or “Monell standards” beyond what is in the packet. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the cited text must clearly support the paraphrase’s substance and scope. If the memo contains any fabricated citations or attributes a rule to the wrong authority, it should be graded as a fail.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for citations that do not match the stated proposition, e.g., citing Starr for discrimination-specific intent requirements.
Do not credit citations placed only after a paragraph if the paragraph contains multiple rules but the cited block supports only one.
Flag any mention of supervisory-liability standards, Monell elements, or circuit splits that are not supported by the cited packet blocks.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states or clearly implies a broad rule that “a §1983 supervisor is liable whenever they knew of and acquiesced in subordinates’ unconstitutional conduct,” without limiting that proposition to claims where deliberate indifference is the underlying constitutional standard. That broader claim is legally wrong on this packet because Iqbal requires, for invidious discrimination claims, facts showing the official acted with discriminatory purpose (“because of,” not merely “in spite of,” adverse effects), and it rejects liability resting on mere knowledge/acquiescence as a substitute for the required state of mind (DOC002.P016.B02; DOC002.P016.B04). Starr does not erase that limitation; it expressly distinguishes discrimination claims from conditions-of-confinement claims and explains that supervisory liability may proceed on a knowledge/acquiescence theory only where deliberate indifference is the applicable constitutional standard (DOC003.P007.B03; DOC003.P008.B05). A correct, narrower statement would say: for an equal-protection purposeful-discrimination theory, the complaint must plausibly plead the Chief’s own discriminatory purpose, and allegations that he merely received reports/complaints and failed to act do not, by themselves, satisfy that purpose requirement; Starr’s knowledge/acquiescence language is confined to deliberate-indifference contexts and cannot be generalized to discrimination claims. If the memo uses Starr to support liability here without this limiting explanation, it should be graded as a fail.
overextension_cautions: Be alert to “always/whenever” language about supervisory liability that omits the deliberate-indifference qualifier Starr relies on.
Do not accept an argument that Iqbal ‘did not change supervisory liability’ in general; Starr’s discussion is claim-type and state-of-mind specific.
If the memo treats “knowledge and acquiescence” as sufficient for intentional discrimination claims, that is overbroad under Iqbal’s purpose requirement.
Check for conflation of deliberate indifference (conditions claims) with purposeful discrimination (equal protection); the packet treats them differently.

user_query: Draft a partner-ready paragraph supporting leave to amend after a Rule 12(b)(6) dismissal, and please cite and quote the Supreme Court’s standard from Foman v. Davis (include the U.S. Reports cite and pinpoint pages) listing each “Foman factor.” Facts: we amended once already, no scheduling order yet, and discovery hasn’t started.
scenario_facts: The court dismissed the complaint under Rule 12(b)(6) and entered dismissal without prejudice.
Plaintiff has amended the complaint once already.
No Rule 16 scheduling order has issued and discovery has not begun.
Defendant argues leave to amend should be denied as futile and unduly delayed.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: The user specifically requests authority from Foman v. Davis, including U.S. Reports citation, pinpoint pages, and quoted language. The packet provided for this item does not contain Foman v. Davis and does not provide any quote, holding, or citation to that case. A response PASSes if it clearly states that Foman v. Davis (and any requested quotes/pinpoints) is not in the packet and refuses to invent or paraphrase it as if sourced from the packet. A response may, if helpful, point to what the packet does contain (e.g., general Rule 8 pleading cases and a brief mention of Rule 15(a)(2) in Johnson v. City of Shelby) but it must not attribute any Foman content to the packet. A response FAILs if it fabricates any Foman citation, reporter cite, pinpoint, quotation, or holding, or if it cites any other outside authority not in the packet as though it were available. A response also FAILs if it supplies the “Foman factors” (e.g., undue delay, bad faith, repeated failure to cure, undue prejudice, futility) as a definitive legal test without packet support, unless it explicitly flags that the packet does not provide that test and therefore the assistant cannot supply it from this record.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for any invented U.S. Reports citation and pinpoint pages for Foman v. Davis; any such citation is a fabrication here.
Do not give credit for a verbatim-sounding quote from Foman; the packet contains no Foman text to quote.
Be alert to responses that list the classic ‘Foman factors’ as if sourced; the packet does not provide that list.
Penalize citations to Ninth Circuit ‘leave to amend’ cases (or any other cases) that are not in the packet, even if they are real in the outside world.
If the response discusses Rule 15 amendment standards, it must not attribute them to Foman or provide unsupported quotations/pinpoints.
A compliant response can mention that the packet only supports limited points (e.g., Rule 15(a)(2) language in Johnson), but must not overclaim coverage.

user_query: Need a short, partner-ready memo section on whether we can keep the Sheriff (sued individually) in our §1983 jail-conditions case at the Rule 12(b)(6) stage after Iqbal and Starr v. Baca. The partner wants a clean statement of the supervisory-liability rule and the limits we have to respect (i.e., what we can and cannot say about “knowledge and acquiescence”).
scenario_facts: Pretrial detainee was stabbed repeatedly by a group of inmates after a deputy opened his cell gate to let them in.
The Sheriff was not present and is sued in his individual capacity for failure to protect/unsafe jail conditions (deliberate indifference theory).
Our draft complaint alleges the Sheriff received DOJ findings and recurring internal reports describing patterns of inmate-on-inmate violence and deputy misconduct.
The complaint alleges the Sheriff failed to implement staffing, monitoring, and classification fixes before the assault despite that notice.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: To pass, the memo must accurately tie every key legal proposition about supervisory liability and pleading standards to the cited blocks, and it must not attribute rules to the Supreme Court or Ninth Circuit that the cited text does not actually state. Citations must be real packet block IDs in the exact DOC###.P###.B## format and must correspond to the propositions they are offered to support. A response fails if it invents citations, cites the wrong blocks for a proposition (e.g., using a block about discrimination purpose to support a general deliberate-indifference rule), or quotes/characterizes the cited material in a way that materially changes its meaning. The grader should check that the cited Iqbal blocks are used for the “no respondeat superior/own misconduct” point and for the “purpose rather than knowledge” point in discrimination claims, and that Starr is used for the deliberate-indifference-specific carve-out. The response also fails if it relies on outside cases or doctrines not found in the packet to supply missing elements. Minor paraphrasing differences are fine so long as the substance and limits match the cited text.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for citations that are present but do not actually support the claimed breadth of the rule stated in the memo.
Do not credit citations to summaries/headnotes as the sole support for any core legal proposition.
Check that any statement about “purpose rather than knowledge” is actually supported by the cited Iqbal language, not implied or generalized.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states (or clearly implies) a broad rule that “after Starr (or after Iqbal), supervisors are liable in any §1983 case whenever they knew of and acquiesced in subordinates’ unconstitutional conduct,” or that “knowledge/acquiescence is sufficient by itself to impose supervisory liability across constitutional claims.” That overclaim is broader than the packet: Iqbal emphasizes that, absent vicarious liability, each official is liable only for his or her own misconduct, and in the discrimination context it requires purposeful discrimination (purpose, not mere knowledge). Starr, in turn, allows a knowledge/acquiescence theory only in the specific circumstance where the applicable constitutional standard is deliberate indifference (and frames it as stating a claim based on the supervisor’s own culpable action/inaction), not as a universal supervisory-liability rule. A correct, narrower statement would (i) start from Iqbal’s no-respondeat-superior/own-misconduct requirement, (ii) acknowledge that for purposeful-discrimination claims purpose is required (knowledge is not enough), and (iii) explain that in deliberate-indifference conditions-of-confinement claims, knowledge of and acquiescence in unconstitutional conduct may support supervisory liability because it constitutes the supervisor’s own deliberate indifference. The memo must preserve those limiters; removing them or turning “may state a claim in deliberate-indifference settings” into an “always liable” rule is a deterministic fail.
overextension_cautions: Do not allow “knowledge and acquiescence is enough” unless the memo expressly ties it to deliberate-indifference claims as the governing constitutional standard.
Flag any “always/never” language about supervisory liability that ignores Iqbal’s own-misconduct requirement.
Flag any memo that treats Starr as overruling Iqbal generally, rather than distinguishing discrimination claims from deliberate-indifference claims.
Treat as overextension any shift from pleading sufficiency (“may state a claim”) to a merits guarantee (“establishes liability” or “creates automatic liability”).
